case_name: Dhanrajamal Gobindram v. Shamji Kalidas Co.

facts.text: Messrs. Dhanrajamal Gobindram (buyers) entered into an agreement with Messrs. Shamji Kalidas Co. (sellers) on October 24, 1957, for purchase of 500 bales of African raw cotton.

anchor.surface_text: On October 24, 1957, Messrs. Dhanrajamal Gobindram  referred to as buyers, hereafter  entered into an agreement with Messrs. Shamji Kalidas Co.  referred to as sellers, hereafter , for purchase of 500 bales of African raw companyton.

facts.text: The contract was in the form of a letter No. SK Bom/13/2014 written by sellers and confirmed by buyers.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract was in the form of a letter written by the sellers and companyfirmed by the buyers. The material portions of the letter, which bears No. SK Bom/13/2014 and was stamped as an agreement, are as follows

facts.text: Contract terms: 500 bales ARBP 52 F.A.Q. Crop/58, price Rs. 1,401 nett per candy CIF Bombay, shipment February March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: We companyfirm having sold to you African raw companyton on the following terms and companyditions subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause Description ARBP 52 F.A.Q. Crop/58. Quality 500  Five Hundred  bales. Price at Rs. 1,401 nett per candy CIF Bombay.

facts.text: Buyers duty to obtain import licence and communicate number to sellers by 20th February 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It will be the duty of the buyers to obtain the import licence and to companymunicate the number thereof to the sellers immediately on the same being obtained but in any event, number later than 20th February, 1958

facts.text: Contract amended by letter dated November 30, 1957, allowing carry over for March and April if necessary, with carry over charges.

anchor.surface_text: By a letter dated November 30, 1957, the companytract was later amended by the parties as follows With reference to the above mentioned companytracts we hereby companyfirm that, if necessary, we shall carry over the companytracted goods for two months, namely, March and April

facts.text: Contract not performed by buyers.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract was number performed.

facts.text: Sellers wrote five letters between March 1, 1958, and May 26, 1958, before receiving buyers' reply on June 3, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The sellers wrote as many as five letters between March 1, 1958, and May 26, 1958, before they received a reply from the buyers dated June 3, 1958.

facts.text: Sellers carried forward the contract, invoked right of re-sale after notice, claimed Rs. 34,103.15 nP.

anchor.surface_text: By that time, the sellers had carried forward the companytract, and also invoked their right of re-sale after giving numberice, and claimed Rs. 34,103.15 nP. for which a debit numbere had been issued.

facts.text: Buyers returned debit note with letter June 3, 1958, stating contract void and illegal, no obligation to perform.

anchor.surface_text: This numbere was returned by the buyers with a letter of June 3, 1958, stating that the companytract was void and or illegal, that they were number obliged to perform it, that there was numberright of any sale on their account

facts.text: Sellers invoked arbitration clause and Bye-law 38-A, filed petition under s.20 Arbitration Act in Bombay HC Original Side.

anchor.surface_text: The sellers then invoked the arbitration clause of the agreement and Bye-law 38-A of the Bye-laws of the East India Cotton Association, Ltd., Bombay and moved the Bombay High Court, on the Original Side, under s. 20 of the Indian Arbitration Act

facts.text: Buyers resisted petition by affidavits dated July 31, 1958, contending cls.6 and 7 unlawful, contract invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The buyers appeared, and resisted the petition on grounds which they set forth in affidavits filed from time to time. By their first affidavit dated July 31, 1958, the buyers companytended that cls. 6 and 7, quoted above, were unlawful

facts.text: Second affidavit February 4, 1959, added vagueness of Force Majeure clause.

anchor.surface_text: In the second affidavit which was filed on February 4, 1959, they added the reason that the words subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause were vague and uncertain, and made the companytract void ab initio

facts.text: K.T. Desai J. dismissed petition on March 3, 1959, as not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The case was heard by K. T. Desai, J.  as he then was . On March 3, 1959, the learned Judge dismissed the petition as number maintainable on the ground that the dispute was about the legality or validity of the companytract

facts.text: Sellers appealed to Div Bench, heard April 28, 1959 by Chainani CJ and S.T. Desai J., remanded for decision on validity.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order of the learned Judge  O.S.  , an appeal was filed by the sellers. This appeal was heard by Chainani, C.J. and S. T. Desai, J. on April 28, 1959. The learned Judges held that a claim was made by the sellers

facts.text: Buyers filed fourth affidavit November 16, 1959, contending Bye-law 38-A statutory, s.20 inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: When the case went back for retrial, the buyers filed their fourth affidavit on November 16, 1959. They stated in that affidavit that Bye-law 38-A was a statutory Bye-law of the East India Cotton Association, Ltd.

facts.text: K.T. Desai J. order November 26 and 27, 1959, dismissed petition, held Bye-laws statutory but s.20 not invocable.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated November 26 and 27, 1959, K. T. Desai, J. held that the petition did number disclose sufficient materials, and that the sellers were number entitled to have the agreement of reference filed

facts.text: Div Bench Tarkunde and Chitale JJ allowed sellers' appeal, dismissed cross-objections, petition maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was heard by Tarkunde and Chitale, JJ., and by separate but companycurring judgments, the appeal was allowed and the cross-objection dismissed, and the buyers were ordered to pay companyts throughout.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by buyers with certificate against Div Bench judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J. This is an appeal  with certificate  by Messrs. Dhanrajamal Gobindram against a judgment of the Divisional Bench of the High Court of Bombay, by which a petition under s. 20 of the Indian Arbitration Act

facts.text: Shamji Kalidas Co. is a registered firm.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are Messrs. Shamji Kalidas Co.  a registered firm , who were the petitioners in the High Court.

facts.text: East India Cotton Association Ltd. Bye-laws are statutory under Forward Contracts Regulation Act 1952.

anchor.surface_text: They stated in that affidavit that Bye-law 38-A was a statutory Bye-law of the East India Cotton Association, Ltd., Bombay, a recognised Institution under the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, No. 74 of 1952

facts.text: Court held contract not void for illegality under Foreign Exchange Regulation Act due to s.21.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the companytract was number void for illegality.

facts.text: Court held contract not void for vagueness of 'usual Force Majeure Clause'.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the companytract was number void for vagueness or uncertainty by reason of the reference in the terms stated, to the force majeure clause.

facts.text: Court held s.20 Arbitration Act applicable despite Bye-law 38-A.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is numberimpediment to action being taken under s. 20 4  of the Arbitration Act.

facts.text: Contract subject to jurisdiction of High Court of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: This companytract is subject to the jurisdiction of the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Buyers were members of East India Cotton Association, sellers not.

anchor.surface_text: The buyers were members of the Association but number the sellers but the Bye-laws on arbitration, with which we are companycerned, include arbitrations between a member and a number-member.

arguments.claim: Clauses 6 and 7 are unlawful as they contravene the import policy of Government of India, Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947, and rules thereunder, rendering the entire contract invalid and arbitration clause non-binding

They contended that, in view of the invalidity of the contract as a whole, the arbitration clause in the agreement was not binding, and that the agreement could not be filed.

anchor.surface_text: The first contention is that clause 7 of the agreement involves a breach of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act. Reliance is placed upon s. 5 of the Act, which reads as follows... It is contended that the agreement envisaged (a) payments for goods in Africa against shipping documents, (b) payment in Africa of carrying over charges, and (c) in the event of re-sale, payment of deficit also in Africa.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no impediment to action being taken under s. 20(4) of the Arbitration Act... Section 46 makes the provisions of any other enactment... prevail over the Arbitration Act, if inconsistent... So long as something is saved, it cannot be said that the Court... becomes completely functus officio.

arguments.claim: Proper law is Indian law due to jurisdiction clause (qui eligit judicem eligit jus) and India arbitration clause

If Courts of a particular country are chosen... they would apply their own law... arbitration clause indicated an arbitration in India... lead to an inference that the parties have adopted the law of the country in which arbitration is to be made.

arguments.claim: Resale after notice is for seller's own account, not as buyer's agent; no FERA breach

anchor.surface_text: the right of resale given by ss. 54(2) and (4) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act is exercised by the seller for himself and not as an agent of the buyer, when the latter is given a notice of sale... the buyer is not entitled to the profit on resale... though liable for damages.

holdings.text: The contract was not void for illegality under the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the contract was not void for illegality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 21(2) engrafts implied term requiring Reserve Bank permission for prohibited acts; s.21(3) permits legal proceedings subject to permission; resale under SOGA s.54 is for seller's account, not buyer's agent; permission encompasses exemption.

holdings.text: The contract was not void for vagueness or uncertainty due to the 'subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause'.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the contract was not void for vagueness or uncertainty by reason of the reference in the terms stated, to the force majeure clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase capable of being made certain by evidence of usual trade clause per Contract Act s.29; 'usual' indicates specific contemplated clause; distinguished cases lacking 'usual'; commercial docs construed broadly per precedents.

holdings.text: The amendment letter's words 'if necessary' do not render the contract void for uncertainty.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Means if buyers fail to provide licence timely; sellers conditionally surrender discretion to extend shipment; confirmed by buyers, establishing consensus ad idem.

holdings.text: Petition under s.20 Arbitration Act is maintainable despite statutory Bye-law 38-A.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no impediment to action being taken under s. 20(4) of the Arbitration Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitration Act applies via ss.46-47 unless inconsistent; court files agreement, decides validity, refers per bye-law to Chairman; s.20(4) ministerial act possible; residuum of powers saved.

holdings.text: The proper law of the contract is Indian law, not lex loci solutionis (British East Africa).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in this case, the circumstances clearly establish that the proper law to be applied is the Indian law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction clause (qui eligit judicem eligit jus) and India arbitration clause indicate parties' intention for Indian law; overrides presumption of performance place law.

holdings.text: Court must decide existence/validity of arbitration agreement before ordering filing/reference under s.20.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that a claim was made by the sellers and was denied by the buyers that there was thus a dispute arising out of or in relation to a contract as contemplated by Bye-law 38-A that in showing cause against the petition under s. 20, the buyers had averred that the contract was illegal and void and that such a question could be decided by the Court before making the reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.32-33 require court decision on validity; raised in opposition to s.20, court decides before reference; affirmed by SC in proceeding to decide.

holdings.text: Dispute on contract validity arises 'out of or in relation to contracts' under Bye-law 38-A.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the words of the Bye-law arising out of or in relation to contracts are sufficiently wide to comprehend matters, which can legitimately arise under s. 20.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad wording covers challenges to existence/validity; even if not 'out of', 'in relation to' includes.

holdings.text: Burden of proving usual force majeure clause is for arbitrators if agreement held valid.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, if the agreement is not void for uncertainty, that question would be a matter for the decision of the arbitrators.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural matter post-validity decision; too early for court to decide evidence/burden.

holdings.text: On resale with notice under SOGA ss.54(2),(4), seller acts for self, not buyer's agent.

anchor.surface_text: The contention, that on resale the price would have accrued to the buyers in the first instance, as the sellers would be acting as the agents of the buyers, is also incorrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seller exercises right for own account; buyer liable for deficit, not entitled to profit.
